channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel Bombs Targets in Syria, and Keeps Up Strikes in Lebanon
item.description: The attack occurred on the same day that Israel bombed sites in the Syrian capital that the Israeli military said were affiliated with a militant group. At least 15 people were killed, Syrian state media reported.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Aaron Boxerman and Euan Ward
item.media:description: Rescuers evacuating bodies from the site of an airstrike that targeted a house in the eastern Lebanese city of Baalbek on Thursday.

item.title: Investigators Assess if Netanyahu’s Aides Forged Oct. 7 Phone Records
item.description: Aides to Benjamin Netanyahu are under investigation over accusations of leaks, record-doctoring and intimidation. The Israeli prime minister’s office denies the claims.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: The inquiry is seen as sensitive in Israel, where the question of what the prime minister knew in advance of Hamas’s invasion could prove crucial to his political future.

item.title: France-Israel Soccer Match is Overshadowed by Amsterdam Attack
item.description: After the recent violence around an Israeli team’s game in Amsterdam, French leaders insisted on proceeding under security with a France-Israel match, and on showing up, themselves.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France (front row, second from the right), Prime Minister Michel Barnier (front left), and former presidents Nicolas Sarkozy and Francois Hollande (behind Mr. Macron) attended the France-Israel soccer match amid heavy security.

item.title: Israel Strikes Humanitarian Zone in Gaza
item.description: The Israeli military said it had been targeting a loaded weapons launcher in the area, where thousands of displaced people are sheltering in a tent camp.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Nader Ibrahim

item.title: Pope Francis Wants to Save the Environment. He Can Start With a Tree.
item.description: Environmentalists have called on the pope to halt the chopping down of a tree destined for St. Peter’s Square this Christmas, but the town providing the tree says it was doomed anyway.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis appearing before crowds from the window of his office overlooking Saint Peter’s Square in December 2023.

item.title: Chemist Identifies Mystery ‘Blobs’ Washing Up in Newfoundland
item.description: A researcher thinks he knows what has been coming ashore on miles of beaches. Canada’s environmental agency says it is still looking into it.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas

item.title: Norway Apologizes for Forced Assimilation of Sami and Other Minorities
item.description: A policy of “Norwegianization” silenced the languages of Indigenous people and forced their children into boarding schools. The long-awaited apology avoided the issue of land rights.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gathering for a reindeer sleigh ride at a Sami Easter Festival in Kautokeino, Norway, in 2018. Norway long had an official policy of suppressing Sami culture.

item.title: Typhoon Usagi Slams Into the Philippines
item.description: The storm made landfall on the island of Luzon. Forecasters warned of torrential rain and landslides in the north of the country.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: A fisherman trying to secure a boat during a storm in Santa Ana, the Philippines, on Thursday.

item.title: Explosions Outside Brazil’s Supreme Court Leave 1 Dead
item.description: Police officials say two blasts near Brazil’s Supreme Court on Wednesday night are being treated as terrorist acts by a lone suicide bomber.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:description: Police officers near the site of an explosion at Three Powers Plaza in Brasília, Brazil’s capital, on Wednesday night.

item.title: Haiti’s Gang Violence Worsens as FAA Suspends Flights From the U.S.
item.description: The country’s security situation has deteriorated even further since Monday when at least three planes were shot at, forcing the closure of its main airport.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Despite the deployment of a Kenyan-led international police force, many parts of Port-au-Prince, Haiti’s capital, remain deserted because of the fear of gangs.

item.title: Mexican Officials Arrest Top Security Official in Mayor’s Beheading
item.description: Mayor Alejandro Arcos Catalán was killed less than a week after taking office in Chilpancingo. On Tuesday, the authorities arrested the city’s public security minister in connection with his death.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and James Wagner
item.media:credit: Jose De La Cruz/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The funeral for Alejandro Arcos Catalán, 43, last month. He was newly elected as the mayor of Chilpancingo, Mexico, when he was killed six days after taking office.

item.title: Notre-Dame Cathedral Is Ready to Reopen in December
item.description: Millions of visitors are expected at the cathedral after it reopens in December for the first time since the devastating 2019 fire.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Taking pictures outside Notre-Dame last year. The cathedral will be reopened on Dec. 7, five years after a devastating fire.

item.title: After Deadly Car Rampage, Chinese Officials Try to Erase Any Hint of It
item.description: Flowers left at the site of the attack, which killed at least 35 people, were quickly removed. Censors deleted videos, articles and comments about it.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: The Zhuhai sports center on Tuesday, the day after a driver killed at least 35 people.

item.title: Trump’s Input in Russia-Ukraine Peace Talks May Put Kyiv on New Timetable
item.description: President-elect Donald J. Trump may accelerate the timetable for a truce. Kyiv views guarantees against renewed aggression as crucial to any settlement.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier repelling a Russian attack at a frontline position near Toretsk last month. Ukrainian forces have been losing ground in the east.

item.title: Why North Korea Is Building Drones
item.description: Analysts say the low-cost weapons are attractive to Mr. Kim, who is intent on modernizing North Korea’s military.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, in a photo released by state media, which said it showed him supervising drone tests on Thursday.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Donald Trump’s provocative cabinet picks.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. campaigning with Donald J. Trump in October.

item.title: In Moscow, Trump’s Victory Is Welcomed, But Warily
item.description: Donald Trump’s re-election victory has dominated media coverage in Russia, where there is restrained optimism about the prospect for better relations.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: A cardboard cutout depicting Donald J. Trump in the window of a bar in St. Petersburg, Russia, three days after he was re-elected.

item.title: Argentina Mulls Exiting Paris Climate Deal
item.description: The South American nation says it is considering withdrawing from the landmark agreement, which aims to limit carbon emissions and slow global warming.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Politi and Ana Ionova
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: President Javier Milei of Argentina is considering withdrawing from the Paris climate agreement, according to the country’s foreign minister.

item.title: Stress From Fireworks Killed Baby Red Panda, Zoo in Scotland Says
item.description: Camera footage showed Roxie, a three-month-old, agitated by the noise. She died shortly afterward.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan

item.title: Murray Sinclair, Who Reframed Indigenous Relations in Canada, Dies at 73
item.description: He headed a commission that documented widespread abuse in Canada’s boarding schools for Indigenous children and sought to correct the history of Indigenous people.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Tim Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: Murray Sinclair in 2021. “We needed individual Canadians to understand not only were Indigenous people mistreated throughout history, but you were lied to as well,” he said.

item.title: Yiannis Boutaris, Vintner, Animal Defender and Greek Mayor, Dies at 82
item.description: A colorful figure in Thessaloniki, he tried to reconcile the city’s painful history with its Turkish and Jewish communities, and he extended a hand to his country’s foes.
item.dc:creator: Iliana Magra
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yiannis Boutaris, the mayor of Thessaloniki, Greece, outside his office in 2012. He said he never thought of himself as a career politician.

item.title: Elon Musk Met With Iran’s U.N. Ambassador, Iranian Officials Say
item.description: The tech billionaire, a top adviser to President-elect Donald J. Trump, was reported to have discussed ways to defuse tensions between Iran and the United States.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Elon Musk after a meeting in Washington on Wednesday.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Dismay Over Trump’s Picks
item.description: Plus, when shopping meets gambling.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Representative Matt Gaetz.

item.title: New York Joins a Global City Club, With a Deal on Congestion Pricing
item.description: The city will be the first in the U.S. to adopt a fee on driving in certain areas, with the aim of reducing traffic and pollution. For some other cities, that has long been the norm.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: New York City is joining many other global cities that have congestion pricing. In most, those fees have become an ordinary part of city life.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: A victory for the Republican Party.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Donald Trump with President Biden, in the Oval Office yesterday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Trump’s Victory Lap
item.description: Plus, an artist sticks up for A.I.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta

item.title: Italy’s President Rebukes Musk for Chiming In on Country’s Immigration Debate
item.description: Sergio Mattarella said Italy “can take care” of itself after Mr. Musk criticized judges who did not approve a government request to hold a group of migrants in Albania.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: President Sergio Mattarella is Italy’s head of state but not part of Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni’s government.

item.title: Canadian Teenager Is Country’s First Human Bird Flu Case
item.description: A teenager in British Columbia was hospitalized in critical condition with the disease, and officials were working to find out how the person was exposed to the virus.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: A colorized electron microscope image of avian influenza grown in cultured cells.

item.title: India’s Top Court Bans ‘Bulldozer Justice’ Often Used Against Muslims
item.description: The tactic, in which state governments raze the homes and businesses of people as acts of retribution, has been on the rise in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Pragati K.B.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shops were razed by the state administration after violent clashes between Hindus and Muslims in Nuh, India, last year.

item.title: Israeli Court Rejects Netanyahu’s Bid to Delay Corruption Trial Testimony
item.description: The court ruled that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu must take the stand on Dec. 2 in a trial that has stretched out for more than four years.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel near Mitzpe Ramon, Israel, last month.

item.title: Who Are Mike Huckabee and Steven Witkoff, Trump’s Middle East Picks?
item.description: Mike Huckabee and Steven Witkoff have both made pro-Israel statements. Here’s a closer look at the two men who will help shape Mr. Trump’s approach in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Mike Huckabee, a former governor of Arkansas, at a campaign event with Donald J. Trump in Pennsylvania last month.

item.title: Blinken Visits NATO Headquarters
item.description: The U.S. secretary of state met with European allies rattled by the American election results at a critical moment for Ukraine and the alliance.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken scheduled his visit to NATO headquarters after the results of the U.S. presidential election.

item.title: Who Might Be the Next Archbishop of Canterbury?
item.description: The leader of the Anglican Church, the Most Rev. Justin Welby, announced he would resign on Tuesday. Here’s what happens next.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The grounds of Lambeth Palace, the residence of the archbishop of Canterbury in London.

item.title: Russia Launches Missiles Against Ukraine’s Capital
item.description: The attack ended a two-month pause in missile strikes on Kyiv, which had only been hit by Russian drones during that period.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Marc Santora
item.media:description: People taking shelter inside a subway station during a Russian military attack, in Kyiv, on Wednesday.

item.title: 2,100 Fakes Rounded Up in Art Forgeries Bust
item.description: Italian officials said they had dismantled a Europe-wide network of forgers and dealers selling works purported to be by A-list artists, mostly through auction houses.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Italian Culture Ministry, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph released by Italy’s Culture Ministry showing fake artworks in Rome after being seized by the police.

item.title: C.I.A. Official Charged in Leak of Classified Documents About Israeli Military Plans
item.description: Asif Rahman, who worked overseas, was arrested on Tuesday by the F.B.I. and faces two counts of violating the Espionage Act.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman and Seamus Hughes
item.media:description: Israeli tanks near the border with Gaza last month. The information in the leaked documents is highly classified and shed light on a possible strike by Israel on Iran.

item.title: COP29 Climate Talks Focus on Financing
item.description: Negotiators agree that trillions are needed to help lower-income countries adapt and cope, but not on who should pay.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles and Brad Plumer
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Delegates at the COP29 climate summit in Baku, Azerbaijan, on Wednesday.

item.title: Gaza Militants Release Video of Sasha Troufanov, an Israeli Russian Hostage
item.description: It was the first sign of Sasha Troufanov since May, when the Palestinian Islamic Jihad militant group posted two videos of him. His family pressed for the release of all the hostages in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: A photo of Sasha Troufanov displayed at a demonstration in Jerusalem last month calling for the release of hostages held in the Gaza Strip.

item.title: Four Tropical Storms Swirl Simultaneously Near the Philippines
item.description: It is the first time on record that more than three tropical storms have occurred at the same time in November in the region.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: A street flooded by heavy rains from Typhoon Toraji in Ilagan, the Philippines, on Tuesday.

item.title: Aid Deliveries to Gaza Remain Low Despite U.S. Warning to Israel
item.description: The Biden administration gave Israel 30 days to increase the flow of aid, warning that aid shipments into Gaza in September had reached an alarmingly low level.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Aaron Boxerman

item.title: Take the ‘Death Stairs’ if You Dare
item.description: A Facebook page, which began among a few friends, has grown into a popular photo collection of hazardous stairs.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: A staircase made of pipe fittings at Kevin Reid’s childhood home in Dublin, Ireland. Each tread can accommodate only one step at a time.

item.title: U.K. Plans to Fine Tech Executives for Illegal Weapon Sales Online
item.description: In a bid to curb knife crime, the government would hold officials of tech companies personally liable for illicit sales on their platforms, a significant shift in internet regulation.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of a charity that works to reduce knife crime reviewing collected items in London in 2022.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Donald Trump’s new appointments.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump has repeatedly complained about not being more rigorous about the people chosen as his aides in his first term.

item.title: U.S. to Keep Sending Arms to Israel Despite Dire Conditions in Gaza
item.description: The State Department said Israel needs to take more steps to improve the situation among Palestinians. The United States had given the country 30 days to meet aid criteria.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Trucks carrying humanitarian aid entered the Gaza Strip from the Erez crossing in southern Israel last month. A letter from the United States to Israel last month said the amount of aid entering Gaza had fallen by 50 percent since April.

item.title: Once They Were Neocons. Now Trump’s Foreign Policy Picks Are All ‘America First.’
item.description: President-elect Donald J. Trump is considering nominees who fit more comfortably within his often erratic worldview, in which deal-making reigns over ideology.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Marco Rubio is under consideration for the role of secretary of state in the new Trump administration.

item.title: 2024 Fossil Fuel Emissions Are Headed for a Record
item.description: Countries promised to move away from coal, oil and natural gas at last year’s climate summit. New research shows they’re burning more than ever before.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: A liquid natural gas terminal in Odisha State, India. Fossil fuel emissions in the country are expected to increase by 4.6 percent in 2024.

item.title: How a Diver Found a Ring Lost 50 Years Ago Near Barbados
item.description: A dive instructor found the well-preserved ring with a metal detector, and then used clues on the ring to try and track down its owner.
item.dc:creator: Hank Sanders

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Trump’s Team of Loyalists
item.description: Plus, the new series “Say Nothing.”
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta

item.title: The UK’s Award-Winning Centenary Building May be Reduced to Rubble
item.description: A building once celebrated for its innovation is deemed obsolete. Those trying to save it ask what its demolition means for British architecture.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel

item.title: Mexico Signals It Could Hit Back With Tariffs at U.S.
item.description: Could a tariff war erupt between the United States and Mexico? A top Mexican official said his country might retaliate if the Trump administration placed steep tariffs on Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Trucks waiting in April in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, to cross into the United States.

item.title: At COP29, Keir Starmer Announces the UK’s Ambitious Climate Targets
item.description: The prime minister announced more ambitious climate targets, charting a very different course from the United States, which is expected to roll back its energy transition plans.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain at the United Nations climate conference in Baku, Azerbaijan, on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Allows Americans to Hold Foreign Conferences With Speakers Under Sanctions
item.description: Reversing itself, the Treasury Department said U.S. sanctions do not prohibit hearing from foreigners deemed to be terrorists or other offenders.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Office of Foreign Assets Control (United States Treasury)
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Hezbollah in Beirut in September.

item.title: A Former Harrods Employee Accuses Al-Fayed of Trafficking and Says His Brother Knew
item.description: In a U.S. court filing, a former employee says she was trafficked, raped and abused when Mohamed al-Fayed owned Harrods, and that his brother Ali may have evidence of the abuse.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Emily Steel
item.media:description: Ali Fayed, the younger brother of Mohamed al-Fayed, in 1989. Now 80, he has a property in Connecticut and is the chairman of a luxury British shirt maker.

item.title: Germany Will Hold Snap Election in February
item.description: After the collapse of Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s governing coalition, the balloting will be held on Feb. 23, about seven months before it had been scheduled.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: The German Bundestag in Berlin.

item.title: Its Birthrate Falling, Russia Targets Child-Free Lifestyles
item.description: The country’s lower house of Parliament passed a law that would ban what it calls “propaganda” discouraging Russians from having children.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Walking on Red Square in Moscow in 2022. A bill passed by lawmakers would ban materials promoting the “conscious refusal to have children” for Russians.

item.title: Italian City in Amanda Knox Case Wants to Move On. A New Series Won’t Let It.
item.description: When a show produced by Ms. Knox about the murder of Meredith Kercher was filmed in Perugia, an outcry by residents led the mayor to apologize.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: One local councilor in Perugia, Italy, said the continued focus on the killing distracted from the city’s “history, art and beauty.”

item.title: Exxon Chief to Trump: Don’t Withdraw From Paris Climate Deal
item.description: Darren Woods was one of only a few Western oil executives attending a global climate conference in Baku, Azerbaijan.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
